More than 25 years ago, the National Arts Centre’s outgoing boss, Peter Herrndorf, was one of the people who first proposed the idea of a national award program for performing artists.

Herrndorf to get GGPA award on his last day at NAC Back to video

This year, he’s getting one of those awards — on his final day at the NAC, no less.

Herrndorf is among this year’s group of laureates named to the Governor General’s Performing Arts Awards. A special award has been created to recognize his long career as an arts advocate and leader.

News of the honour came as a surprise to Herrndorf, who has spoken with many of the dozens of artists who have received GGPA awards over the years, from Joni Mitchell and Leonard Cohen to Robert Lepage and Christopher Plummer.

“In every case they tell me how moved and honoured they are,” Herrndorf said. “I’m surprised to find myself in the same situation, deeply honoured and moved.”

The award marks a full-circle moment for the 77-year-old. In 1992, he and a music-industry colleague, Brian Robertson, brought their pitch for creating the highest honour in the land for artists to then-governor general Ramon Hnatyshyn, who was a keen supporter.

“There were several goals,” Herrndorf said. “One was to bring prestige and honour to artists who were doing exceptional work but may not have been as recognized as they needed to be. Another was to make sure that francophone artists became much better known in English-speaking Canada, and English-speaking artists became known in French-speaking Canada.”

Under the patronage of Gov. Gen. Julie Payette, this year Herrndorf is being recognized for his leadership. He was a journalist, broadcaster and avid NAC patron before he took the helm of the Ottawa institution almost 19 years ago.

“I had always been very impressed with the artists it attracted, the size and complexity of the place,” he said, “but I was also nervous about the state it was in. Ultimately I thought it was so important to the country, and such an interesting challenge that it proved irresistible. It was a great decision. I’ve loved the 19 years. It’s been one of those dream jobs. I work with terrific people. It’s been fun, and very rewarding.”

He’s credited with transforming the NAC — North America’s only multidisciplinary, bilingual performing arts centre — into an artistically vibrant and financially viable entity. He oversaw the recent $225.4-million architectural rejuvenation of the institution, and was instrumental in launching the new department of Indigenous theatre, which is gearing up for its debut season in 2019.

Until now, his work has always been behind the scenes. “As I’ve said so many times, nobody ever bought a ticket to see Peter Herrndorf chair a meeting,” he jokes.

One of the secrets to Herrndorf’s success at the NAC has been his support of women in positions of leadership. Many of the centre’s artistic directors and senior managers are women, including English theatre’s Jillian Keiley, NAC Presents’ Heather Gibson and dance producer Cathy Levy, to name a few.

“This is an organization that has benefited tremendously from very gifted women, both on the artistic side and the management side in the performing arts,” he said. “It’s really thrilling when you see women of this calibre have the kind of impact they’re having. In many ways, we’re the poster child for the women’s movement.”

The laureates will be toasted during a series of events, culminating in a black-tie gala at the NAC on June 2, Herrndorf’s last day of work at the centre.

Here’s the complete list of 2018 winners announced Thursday:

Angela Hewitt: The Ottawa-born classical pianist, a four-time Juno winner, is considered the world’s foremost interpreter of Bach. She’s about half-way through her Bach Odyssey, a mission to present Bach’s opus in its entirety, with 12 recitals over four years.

Murray McLauchlan: The singer-songwriter has 11 Juno Awards, is known for his socially conscious songs and support of songwriters’ rights. His songs include Farmer’s Song, Down by the Henry Moore and Honky Red, recently recorded by the U.S. jam band Widespread Panic.

Genevieve Bujold: The Quebec actress has been lighting up Hollywood screens since the 1960s, including a riveting performance as Anne Boleyn in 1969’s Anne of The Thousand Days, which earned her a Golden Globe Award and an Oscar nomination.

Andrew Alexander: The comedy impresario who founded The Second City and SCTV has a knack for recognizing brilliant comedic talent. He launched the careers of Gilda Radner, Dan Aykroyd, John Candy, Andrea Martin, Eugene Levy, Catherine O’Hara and others.

Ginette Laurin: The dancer/choreographer founded the Montreal dance company O Vertigo, and is a pioneer of the contemporary dance movement in Quebec.

Tegan and Sara: The openly gay twin-sister pop duo will receive the NAC Award in recognition of their work over the past year. In addition to the success of their latest studio album, the pop-oriented Love You To Death, they started a charitable foundation to fund programs that support trans women and women of colour. (The NAC Award is a mid-career award).

Florence Junca Adenot: The longtime champion of the arts in Quebec gets the Ramon John Hnatyshyn Award for Voluntarism in the Performing Arts.
